Australia condemns terrorist activity, whoever is responsible for it. We offer our hand in friendship to Turkey. Without in any way attempting to dictate to them how they should handle affairs within their country, we do as a friend offer our support to combat terrorism and to ensure that humanitarian approaches are always maintained in respect of those sorts of problems.

As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, our strong links with Turkey arose because of our shared experience in Gallipoli. This was, I suppose, the origin of the Australian-Turkish relationship, because there was not much before Gallipoli. This incredible experience between our two countries created bonds of respect unique amongst former enemies. These bonds are built on today and are mentioned constantly at modern ceremonies celebrating Anzac Day in Australia. I was very moved, as I am sure most Australians have been, by the words of the former Turkish commander Ataturk in 1934 when he was writing to an Australian mother about the experience. I will quote some of his words, because I think they can be recorded today in the Hansard appropriately. He wrote:

Those heroes that shed their blood and lost their lives . . . you are now lying in the soil of a friendly country. Therefore rest in peace. There is no difference between the Johnnies and the Mehmets to us where they lie side by side here in this country of ours . . . You the mothers, who sent their sons from far away countries, wipe away your tears: your sons are now lying in our bosom and are in peace. After having lost their lives on this land they have become our sons as well.

That is an incredible set of words and a tribute that lives on. It is good to see how our relationship with Turkey in respect of trade is growing dramatically; it was commented on by the member for Maribyrnong. Australian exports to Turkey in 1997-98 were $636 million, which is an increase of 66 per cent when compared with the previous decade. Imports from Turkey were $112 million, so we have a trade advantage with Turkey. The trade from Turkey to Australia has in fact increased by 51 per cent in that same period of time.

Turkey is now our 25th largest export market. They are good trading partners, and we enjoy harmonious relations in the business sector with Turkish people. Very often within Turkey we form joint ventures with Turkish citizens and businesses. Our exports are greater to Turkey than to other countries in the surrounding region, and in fact greater than to many European and Asian countries. Our exports have also diversified each year as we find new markets and opportunities, mainly commodity based. Our most exciting recent export is the sale to Istanbul of fast ferries by a company in Western Australia. We wish all of those people every success in that exciting trade agreement involving Australian technology. No doubt other countries will see our products and wish to buy. There is no question about that; there is great scope for further expansion of our trade.

It is good to see that Turkey is also becoming a country where the very large number of poor people are able to improve their lot each year. Turkey has a rapidly growing middle class, as it is described, due to that enterprise. In fact, Turkey's GNP growth in 1997 was 8.3 per cent. Unfortunately, they have very high inflation. I understand it is in excess of 50 per cent, but they have brought it down from 80 per cent and are working hard on it. We wish them well in the struggle to manage their economy efficiently and to fight the scourge of inflation.

In summary, Turkey is a modern, dynamic and secular state. We are pleased to see the emerging strengthening of their democratic parliament. Although they have had many difficulties over the years, we see that they are struggling with, and making good progress, ensuring that on the domestic front the people of Turkey of all backgrounds are being given an increasing role in the every day life of that democratic place. It is with pleasure that we also acknowledge at this time, as I said at the beginning of my contribution, the continuing contribution of people of Turkish origin in Australia.

talk.start.para: —The motion and the earlier speakers have noted that the initiation of the contact between Turkey and Australia was not all that auspicious—many of us have family members who fought the Turks in the First World War not only at Gallipoli, where most of this is focused, but also in the wider Middle East.

speech.para: Symptomatic of that tie today is one of the schools in my own electorate, Granville Boys High School, which has a very significant Turkish population. Every year their ceremonies of remembrance for Gallipoli entail a number of Turkish aspects: the Turkish band in the school, the recitation of their poem Cannakale, speeches that stress the mutual loss and, as other speakers alluded to, Ataturk's comments in regard to Australian troops who died at Gallipoli having another home there. From that, very strong relationships have grown. They have been shown in our mutual UN activity in conflicts such as Korea, our trade connections and our various cultural exchanges—most recently in Sydney at the Turkish Film Festival.

I think many people have an interest in Turkey because it is a secular state in its region. This year the Turkish community in Australia, and those within Turkey, have been celebrating the 75th anniversary of the declaration of the republic. The declaration of the republic involved a number of political trends that are of some importance even today: the abolition of the caliphate in 1924; Ataturk's pressure for Westernisation of dress; most emphatically, the declaration that Turkey would be a secular state; the introduction of the Latin alphabet; and the abolition of polygamy. All of those are aspects of Turkish society which most of us in Australia would overwhelmingly support and endorse. It is important in 1998 that we do stand with the Turkish government in attempting to ensure the preservation of those aspects.

The motion also deals with Turkish migration to this country. As has been noted, that has been in practice for about 30 years. Remittances are actually very important to the Turkish economy. In 1997, $4,229 million went from Turkish overseas workers and residents back to the Turkish economy. It is an economy that has been growing fairly strongly for most of the last 10 to 15 years, but it has, unfortunately, been characterised by heavy inflation and a relatively high government debt.

Turkish migration in this country was not assisted because it actually was fairly simultaneous with the onset of the boat people. A number of government analyses of migration assistance and settlement help in this country have put forward the proposition that the Turks were to some degree disadvantaged in comparison with a number of other recent arrival groups because our focus in that period of their ascendant migration was perhaps not as strongly helped because of our emphasis on the boat people. Yet, despite that, the Turks in Australia have a real presence increasingly in the professions, in more recent years not only through greater migration by people with those skills but also through second generation Turks going through our university system. I see in my own electorate the increasing number of Turkish lawyers, doctors, pharmacists, psychiatrists, et cetera. That is another part of the motion that is very accurate.

Finally, the motion notes the way in which the Turkish community has played a very constructive role in a number of controversial matters. Although not specifically mentioned, one of those was the decision by the two major parties in the New South Wales parliament to erect a monument there commemorating the Armenian massacres of the postwar period. The question is not the argument over what occurred then but whether we should single out one nationality for a monument for this type of thing and basically increase ethnic tensions in this country. I think it was a very unfortunate decision and I again urge the state government of New South Wales and the opposition to look at the constructive way in which the Turkish community has dealt with this very controversial decision.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to support this motion about a nation friend on the world stage—a nation which is an ancient land, just like Australia, but a nation which has enjoyed the concept of civilisation, as we know it these days, for a great deal of time. Indeed, it is an area which encompasses the cradle of civilisation, an area I was able to visit about 14½ years ago as a journalist with Channel 7. I was totally impressed by the way in which the Turkish people rightly hold their history—very proudly.

speech.para: In fact, Turkey struck me as a nation of great contrast and conflict. One of the great ironies for Turkey is that, when God created earth, it was made to straddle two of the great tectonic plates on this planet—where Europe meets Asia in both the physical, ground sense and in a cultural sense. So that in itself really personifies what Turkey, the nation we know today, has been like throughout the ages.

These days, as has been noted, it is a secular state where different cultures and beliefs are living side by side; where modern buildings along the beachfronts are the places where German, French and European tourists go—to Kusadasi, a modern port town, near the ancient city of Ephesus, which is just a few miles up the road. It is a place that I believe all Australians aspire to visit because of the conflict at Gallipoli in the early part of this century. That names such as Suleiman the magnificent, the Ottoman Empire and Ataturk sit very strongly in Australia's collective memory really does say something about Turkey the modern nation and its role in the modern world. The city of Istanbul—once known as Constantinople, once known as Byzantium, once known as the new Rome—throughout the ages has produced great civilisations and great centres of activity and commerce, and these days it is a city where Byzantine mosques are amazing remnants of the past. Some started as Christian cathedrals built during the great crusades.

Australia and Turkey enjoy a very special relationship, which I guess is at the heart of why I am happy to support this motion today recognising the importance of that relationship so far as our trade relationship with Turkey is concerned these days. I know in lots of ways it is a very Australian and also a very Turkish relationship that two nations who were on either side of horrendous warfare in the early part of the century should complete this century as very close friends. It is a relationship built on a great deal of respect that the leader of modern Turkey, General Ataturk, encapsulated in his comments, paraphrased by those opposite: `A message to Australian mothers: that you, the mothers who sent their sons from far away countries, wipe away your tears. Your sons are now lying in our bosoms and are in peace. Having lost their lives on this land they become our sons as well.' Those words did a lot to unify the great tensions that once existed between Australia and Johnny Turk.

The landings at Gallipoli hold a special place in the hearts and minds of all people in Australia. I have only to look at the street to the north and the street to the south of my electorate office in Ipswich Road, Moorooka to see Gaba Tepe Street to the north and Helles Street to the south and to know that in so many ways places in Turkey—and those two streets are named after key locations; in fact, the location of the second landing in the case of Gaba Tepe at Anzac Cove—link two very important parts of Australian history and our conflict in Turkey. Australians rightly pride themselves on building a strong friendship with Turkey, and I believe the Turks rightly pride themselves on building a strong friendship with Australia.

When I was in Turkey in 1984 the people there were talking about the television program East of Eden and were amazed to find out that crocodiles were not taking Australians on a constant and regular basis. They are seeing a little bit of Australian culture just as Australians are being blessed to see Turkish culture. This is a nation that beat us in war, yet a nation that has extended us great courtesy and respect. Likewise, we hold a great deal of respect for the fighting spirit of the Turks. That landing at Gallipoli has forged a strong friendship between our two countries and this motion today, I think, emphasises the importance of building on that relationship now and into the future.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) notes the increasing number of closures of bank branches within the Australian community;

(2) agrees to refer the issue of bank closures to the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs to take evidence as appropriate and consider appropriate recommendations to place before the House; and

(3) determines that, as well as the general reference, the standing committee also inquire into and report on the increasing number of service reductions within communities and the increas ing difficulties with which remaining services are able to be contacted by local residents where services are reduced or removed.

The closure of bank branches is a major concern of residents all over Australia. Communities both in the city and the country have been deprived of vital community services, particularly banks but also employment services, Medibank offices and many others. In particular I will refer, firstly, to the closure of the Lalor Park branch of the Commonwealth Bank within my electorate of Greenway. While there have been over 200 Commonwealth Bank closures across Australia, the closure of the Lalor Park branch was the straw that broke the camel's back. The expression of anger by the Lalor Park community at the bank's decision has hit the media headlines right across Australia. It has resulted in an unprecedented advertising campaign by the Commonwealth Bank to try to defend itself by painting a very rosy picture of its operations.

Bank closures have become an issue of national importance. The Federal Treasurer, the member for Higgins, in an interview on ABC Radio just prior to the re-opening of this parliament was asked whether the federal government would legislate to prevent bank closures. He replied that, no, the government would not legislate to prevent bank closures any more than they would legislate to prevent milk bars closing—or words to that effect. This statement shows that the federal Treasurer, and I suggest the government, do not understand the particular economic and social significance that a bank has for a local community or a country town.

The Lalor Park branch of the Commonwealth Bank was situated in a busy strip shopping centre adjacent to a council car park. In most cases residents could walk or, if they travelled by car, could get out and walk straight to their bank, their local newsagent, fruit shop, butcher and Jewel food store. The shopping centre also contains a post office and a TAB. The viability of this shopping centre is seriously threatened by this bank closure. Local small business people will suffer financial loss just to increase the bank's profits. The people who settled in Lalor Park were generally working-class people, labour ers, trades people, public servants, clerks and building workers. Many of the people who moved into this area in the early 1960s are now nearing retirement, or have retired.

There are also a number of departmental housing units that house many pensioners. The pensioners, both aged and invalid, rely on the Commonwealth Bank to collect their pension. Under these new arrangements, pensioners will have to travel to other locations at considerable cost to themselves to do their banking or shopping. With the increased bank fees recently imposed by the bank, plus the additional cost in travelling to other locations, pensioners are going to be considerably worse off even before the GST comes into operation. But, to balance the area's ageing community, there are also two large primary schools. Their enrolment of some 700 children indicates a substantial young population which the Commonwealth Bank appears to ignore as potential bank customers.

It came as a shock to the Lalor Park branch customers when they were advised that the bank would close. They were advised on 11 September that the bank would close on 23 October. The bank's letter stated that the decision to close the bank was taken only after a thorough investigation of all factors affecting the bank's business. It was very interesting to note that at this point the customers had not been advised or consulted about the bank's closure. Two protest meetings were held in the local shopping centre and were attended by several hundred residents. An action committee was formed to oppose the bank closure. Mr John McConnell, the local newsagent, was elected as president of that committee, a local resident who was actually the holder of Commonwealth Bank shares. A local Catholic priest was involved and several residents representing pensioners and other groups formed part of this committee.

A protest meeting which was also held outside the Commonwealth Bank building in Martin Place resulted in several members of the action committee obtaining a meeting with Mr David Murray, the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Mr Murray accused members of the action com mittee of developing a politically inspired campaign. This was very untrue because all the local political representatives provided was support for a local community shocked that it was to lose a vital community asset. The local political representatives, Mr Leo Kelly, a councillor on Blacktown Council, John Aquilina, the state member for Riverstone and the state minister for education and I all felt we had a clear responsibility to support the local residents in their fight against the closure of this particular bank.

I got the impression—I was not present during the meeting with Mr Murray but I was present during other meetings—that the bank management were very uncomfortable about explaining their position to the committee. They were not prepared to give detailed reasons for the closure other than to say in their letter to customers that `business levels had not met our expectations to the extent that continued operation of the bank is no longer viable.' This is a very ambiguous statement, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you can appreciate. The statement does not even suggest that there had been a reduction in business at this particular branch but only that business levels had `not met our expectations'.

Clearly it is possible for any bank to either promote or reduce their business in a particular location to meet their commercial targets without consideration of their public service responsibilities. In the case of the Lalor Park branch, the alternative arrangements suggested by the bank, such as the use of the banking facilities in a small post office, travelling to other locations or the use of autobank facilities, all fell short of the face-to-face banking services that previously applied at the Lalor Park branch.

My colleague the member for Barton, who is seconding this motion, has also seen his constituents suffering bank closures at Penshurst and Carlton. I had the pleasure of attending a public meeting of councils in that area and saw the concern that they all felt about these closures and the effect upon the local people. Local government in New South Wales is exploring the possibility of countering bank closures by establishing community banks, as is occurring in Victoria. I have been informed by Councillor Leo Kelly, Vice-President of the New South Wales Local Government Association, that his organisation has set up a task force to examine a proposal to establish a community bank using the facilities and financial backing of local government. Nationally, local government has about $10 billion invested with the big four banks, and the Australian Local Government Association will be monitoring the New South Wales move into the banking sector. The New South Wales local government task force will be chaired by Councillor Woods, President of the New South Wales Local Government Association, who is a very experienced administrator. The Woods task force is expected to make recommendations by April next year.

What seems to be recognised by all but the banks is that banks are somewhat more vital to a local community than, say, a milk bar. Some regulations need to be introduced to ensure that banks are responsive to community needs. In Canada, for example, banks are required to meet strict community service requirements before they can retain their banking licences. The Secretary of the NSW and ACT branch of the Financial Sector Union, Mr Geoff Derrick, has suggested that a small levy on profits, probably set at less than 1 per cent of total profits, could be established and a rebate offered, depending on the strength of the community services offered.

Ms Maree Bun of the Australian Consumers Association has suggested that a tax based on the American Community Reinvestment Act should be explored. The American reinvestment act rates American banks' commitment to community services in areas such as lending, deposits and transactions. Statutory deposits are used to fund gaps in services created by low ranking banks, while aiming to ensure that disadvantaged areas have access to finance and services. Likewise, essential service conditions similar to those attached to, say, Telstra and Australia Post should be applied to banks.

All of these and many other ideas could be the subject of a very thorough examination by our relevant House committee, as suggested in this motion. In my view, we would be doing something very positive for all of our people. There have been many fine inquiries that have delivered good suggestions for governments to take up, and the referral suggested in this motion has the potential to excite the many people who have been so poorly treated as a result of bank closures. I am hopeful that, since this issue is of such a major concern across party and electorate lines, we can get approval for a referral of this matter for proper and careful inquiry.

I am aware that I have been speaking in the main about bank closures in the city, but I am also very much aware that the issue is probably even more serious in the country areas. Since my time is up, I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—In listening to the member for Greenway, I must admit that I do share the concerns he has for the residents of Lalor Park. I know that when a bank branch is closed it always causes great concerns in the local community. But, as I continued to listen to his speech, it did strike me as rather strange that he was talking about the Commonwealth Bank. I thought about it a bit further and thought, `Hang on a minute. The Commonwealth Bank used to be owned by the government.' And, when he made reference to community service obligations such as with Australia Post or with Telstra, which are owned, or majority owned, by the government, I thought, `Who sold the Commonwealth Bank?' I could not help but think there was something missing here. He really should have been making those views known some time ago when the Labor Party was in power, because it was the Labor Party, of course, that made the decision to sell down the Commonwealth Bank. I listened to his solution when he was talking about levies and I could not help thinking, `Is this some new form of services tax that he is proposing to solve the problems as he sees them?'

speech.para: I do want to talk about a couple of issues, one of which the member did allude to at the end of his speech: what is happening in country areas. In the last parliament I was chair of the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration, which was looking at the whole question of banking services and alternatives to banking services in rural and regional Australia. While that report has not yet been tabled, I can assure all honourable members that there was a considerable amount of very constructive work done, in a bipartisan way, looking at the whole issue of banking services in regional and rural Australia and in remote areas as well. I anticipate that when the report is tabled in the parliament there will be some quite positive recommendations to be put to the government.

I also want to talk a little about the third part of the motion of the member for Greenway regarding the increasing number of service reductions. I could not help thinking, when I was looking at that, about my own experience yesterday—which I remind honourable members was a Sunday—when I paid my Bankcard bill. I did not have to walk down to the local branch. I did not have to go in there while the branch was open, which is only limited hours, and I did not have to walk through the rain or anything else. I was sitting at my desk. I picked up my telephone and I rang the bank and paid the bill on a Sunday afternoon. I thought, `This is actually an improved service. It is not a reduction, it is actually an improving service.'

When we come to debate these issues in the chamber, we should recognise that change is here and in many cases there are a lot of changes for the better. When we look at some of the changes in availability of services and the growing use of service centres for all sorts of services for which in the past it was necessary to have a face-to-face interaction, we find that through service centres—those run by government agencies and also those run by businesses—we have better services. We have access generally over longer hours, and we certainly have much quicker access. While there may have been some teething problems in some areas, mostly they are being worked out.

This means that people, whether they are busy people or the elderly, can often get access to a greater range of services at very low cost and certainly, in most cases, much more quickly. For example, it is now possible, as I mentioned, to pay bills 24 hours a day, seven days a week. We can use a telephone to do business with most of the major banks. Most major banks now have customer service officers available via the telephone for at least 12 hours a day, which is far more than if you had to go into the bank itself.

Other agencies, insurance companies, utilities and other government services with call centres are often available now where there was none in the past—so nothing has been lost because there was never anything there. We ought to put this motion into perspective and try to keep some balance. It concerns me that this motion concentrates very much on the negative aspects and overlooks some of the positive aspects of the changes that are occurring in the community, many of which are for the better.

We have seen a lot of changes in banking services, many for the better but not all, I admit. For example, by the end of 1997 there were 7,800 automatic teller machines throughout Australia. These provide access to a service with extended hours which is often in places where there was limited service access. I know that some people have difficulty with ATMs, but we have also seen a massive growth in the use of EFTPOS. There is no doubt that this has made basic withdrawal services very easy for many bank customers. At the end of 1997, there were 75,000 EFTPOS terminals throughout Australia—far more than there are bank branches. Again, for most people an EFTPOS system is quicker when it comes to getting hold of cash. It is also much more accessible and is available for extended hours. A bank branch does not have that.

Members who were on the Financial Institutions and Public Administration References Committee know that a number of alternative ways of providing banking are becoming more prevalent. The member for Greenway mentioned community banks. In my state, the Bank of Bendigo has started community bank branches in the Wimmera and is looking to set up at least one in suburban Melbourne. There is no doubt that, where communities choose to go down this path, it offers some very exciting alternatives to a traditional bank branch. The odds are that they are going to get a greater range of services than they probably had in the past, and they are certainly going to get some other community benefits from going down that path.

There are others, too. For example, Bank SA has set up an agency system—initially throughout South Australia, but it is now moving into Victoria. There are now at least two such agencies in my electorate: at Penshurst—and I jumped when you mentioned Penshurst, because Penshurst is in my electorate—and also Macarthur. These agencies allow a local business to put in a basic transaction service for people, generally in a local store.

Bank SA has nearly 200 of those in place. Again, they allow people face-to-face basic transaction services, almost always with much greater accessibility from the point of view of hours of the day during which they can access it than they have with an ordinary bank branch. Again, that is a positive development. It is something that also overcomes the problem of the face-to-face service that some of the pensioners and elderly people have difficulty with because it means that they are probably dealing with a person they have great confidence in and have known for many years.

The major banks are also realising—to quite a large extent as a result of the work the standing committee has done—that this policy of continuing to close bank branches is not good business and is not helping their image in the community. The ANZ has announced a freeze on bank closures. Westpac is putting agencies into places where there is no longer a bank branch. Likewise, a number of the other banks are exploring the question of setting up bank agencies and expanding that process. This shows that, while there are changes, nonetheless a lot of these changes are providing an equivalent service and, in some cases, a better service.

The credit care process has been put in place, whereby credit unions are set up where there is no bank branch. Australia Post has expanded giroPost, and we hope to see more happening there. This often means that people have an alternative. Just last weekend, pharmacists announced that 3,000 pharmacists are likely to be used as agents for one of the banks. That is an extended service by people whom the community generally have a high regard for. As the honourable member mentioned, local government is also looking to do something. While I understand the sentiments behind this motion, I think it is a bit narrow and overlooks some of the positive developments that are occurring throughout our community.

talk.start.para: —I wish to reply to a couple of points made by the previous speaker, the member for Wannon. It is interesting that he noted that the community service obligation was removed after the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. We will be interested to hear the views of the member for Wannon in respect of the legislation to privatise Telstra and what effect that will have on its service obligations to the community—in particular, the rural community.

speech.para: It is difficult to ascertain where the member for Wannon stands on this issue of bank closures. It is an issue which has chronically affected my electorate. A suburb in my electorate called Penshurst has lost its bank branch—and the member for Wannon also has a town called Penshurst—and so has the suburb of Carlton. We have lost Commonwealth Bank branches in those two suburbs.

That has had a dramatic effect on customers of the Commonwealth Bank. Some customers have not had the opportunity to learn how to use new technology. Senior citizens, in particular, are a little timid of those sorts of advances, as are people from non-English speaking backgrounds, who are tentative about that sort of equipment. Generally, people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds do not have the economic pull that wealthier areas have and so they have suffered more from these bank closures.

From the local business community's point of view—and the member for Wannon did not address these concerns adequately in his reply—it means that the drawcard that a bank has to the local community is removed. There is no doubt about it: banks themselves draw people into the area and that flows onto other shops in the vicinity. So those two shopping centres at Penshurst and Carlton are significantly under threat as a result of the closure of the banks.

In addition, those businesses require cash for their day-to-day operations. They need to obtain till money and deposit it at the end of the day. Those facilities have been removed from them. In a reply to my concerns, the Commonwealth Bank pointed out alternative banking options within a radius of seven miles, I think it was. But it is unsatisfactory for these small business owners, many of whom have one or two people working in the business, to travel that distance to another banking area. There is also a security issue involved there.

There is a community service obligation imposed on the banks. In the case of the Commonwealth Bank, the chief executive, David Murray, indicated disdain, if you like, for the views of the community when he said that people should be writing letters of congratulation to the banks for closing branches. That is in the context of the Commonwealth Bank having a profit, I think, of $1.09 billion—not million—last year and being responsible for increasing a whole range of charges. His heartless comment in the context of those bank closures has really backfired because with a lot of impetus from local governments in my area, as the member for Greenway indicated, there is now a real push on by the Local Government Association to remove their banking from the Commonwealth Bank, and that is worth about $4 billion—not million. There is also a push on to establish a local government bank. If banks continue to demonstrate this heartless attitude to not only their customers but also local communities there is no doubt that there is going to be a push for these sorts of develop ments to flow on, as the member for Wannon indicated in an example in Bendigo.

The banks should not think that we in this parliament or indeed the population are helpless to meet what they are doing. Clearly, if the marketplace, which is under their control, is not satisfying the community's expectations, the government have an obligation to step in. If they do not look at what they are doing they may well see a resolution from this parliament introducing obligations similar to the Community Reinvestment Act in the United States whereby banks, unless they meet a certain minimum criteria, have to contribute to a fund to subsidise the provision of those services by other institutions.

So banks are firmly put on notice—not only by this parliament but also by the parliament of New South Wales, which passed a unanimous resolution condemning their closures—that the community has really come to the end of tolerating these closures. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I had the pleasure of returning to my electorate on Friday evening to open the branch of a bank in one of the little rural towns in New England, right up on top—a little village by the name of Guyra. That epitomises, I think, a lot of the changes that are taking place in regional and rural Australia. The story of it is quite interesting.

speech.para: A number of years ago the Commonwealth bank actually left town, as they had in a lot of places in regional Australia. The premises in due time came up for purchase. Amongst the businesses that operated in the little village of Guyra were some insurance people—in fact, the second generation coming through—who were looking to expand their business. They were looking to move out of rented premises and into their own premises. Being the enterprising people they are, they put in a reasonable bid for the purchase of the old Commonwealth Bank building in the town of Guyra. They were successful and duly moved their business into that particular building.

As towns go through changes they start to embrace their own futures. The people who took over that building, David and Lisa Harris, were determined to be able to provide more than simply insurance services from the building. They looked to see whether they could provide banking services for the people of the village and the surrounding district. After a fairly long period of negotiation they were successful and, as I say, on Friday evening I had the great pleasure and honour of opening a branch of the Colonial State Bank in our town and seeing a new bank come to a regional area. It was done because people decided to create their own future and to start to embrace those opportunities that are there in regional Australia. Coming from a country and rural area, I think some very exciting opportunities and developments in the provision of services generally to people who live in regional Australia are going to come.

In searching around for some information further afield on the question of services, I looked to Tasmania where a small town by the name of Triabunna on Tasmania's east coast was also suffering a downturn. However, the town's future and fortunes appear to have changed again because Westpac has returned to Triabunna. The branch itself and the tellers have gone, perhaps for good, as you have seen before, but in their place is something very new in government—the private sector with service delivery.

The massive reform began slipping quietly into place earlier this year down there. Its network spreads across the state, with a new shop opening almost every week. The first Service Tasmania shop opened in Hobart in January this year, offering locals access to more than 150 government services. That was followed by Smithton, on the north-west coast, and then the Queenstown shop, which is providing access to state government services and Centrelink in the one location. Queenstown is a pilot project, demonstrating how state and federal governments can work together to eliminate duplication and to make life easier for those doing business with government. Rural Campbelltown's new Service Tasmania shop will also offer local government services when it opens later this month as the two-year project evolves to provide more shared service facilities.

Technology driven change in the wider community is having an immeasurable and positive impact in terms of both general public and public sector acceptance. Impressed by the Service Tasmania model and its flexibility to absorb other services, the federal coalition recently announced its $70 million pre-election policy to establish 500 one-stop shops across rural Australia. In implementing its promise, the government is likely to draw heavily on that wonderful experience in Tasmania. For the people of rural and remote communities around Australia, information technology and one-stop shopping are an economic reality in the age of rationalism. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —My grievance relates to the failure of the Howard government to recognise that Australian working people expect their government to see job creation as a priority. I contend that the Howard government has avoided its key responsibility to create new jobs and to defend existing jobs. Senator Nick Minchin has only been in his new industry portfolio for a couple of weeks, yet he has quickly dropped an old Howard government promise. It was a very important promise: to create 200,000 additional jobs in the manufacturing industry by the year 2000.

speech.para: I, like many in the Australian community, was amazed at the arrogant and dismissive manner in which he walked away from the government's commitment to create additional manufacturing jobs in an interview on the Channel 9 Sunday program yesterday. In response to a question relating to that target of 200,000 jobs in manufacturing by 2000, he said, in a very dismissive way:
Yeah, well, that's not a target we're pursuing in this term.

What confidence can we have in this government's commitment to job creation with comments such as that, when such a key ally of the Prime Minister is prepared to drop a core Howard government promise? That is what it was; it was one of the real commitments to a target on the issue of jobs at the commencement of the Howard government's reign in March 1996.

I also refer to Senator Minchin's fellow minister, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, who knows that he has failed to produce the goods with regard to job creation. He promised Australians wonderful new jobs once his first workplace relations laws came into operation in December 1996. Now Minister Reith hopes to create jobs by further slashing away at the basic job rights and job security of working Australians.

This government has given up on creating better jobs by building on a good, decent employment system. They want to create jobs by destroying our employment system and by cutting into basic rights. They want to further undermine the security of those already in work by amending further workplace laws to cut unfair dismissal rights and to cut the pay and conditions of our young people.

A government with vision about jobs would be looking at what has happened in regional Australia. Jobs are gone thanks to their anti Public Service and anti community sector policies, as well as populations in decline. On that note, I need only refer to the level of unemployment in some of those regional seats. Let us take Hinkler, in regional Queensland, where there is currently a level of unemployment of 13.2 per cent. Richmond, in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales, which is again a seat held by the National Party, has a level of unemployment of 14.8 per cent. Adelaide, in South Australia, a seat held by the Liberal Party, has an unemployment level of 10.3 per cent. There are many other seats but I will finish with Longman, in Queensland, where unemployment as of June 1998 has stood at 11.8 per cent.

Clearly, unemployment is of crisis proportions in Australia, especially in regional Australia. That is borne out by further reports in the media today, which show a concentration of job growth in metropolitan Australia in areas such as Sydney and Melbourne, while regional Australia not only continues to lose out but also represents areas of huge job losses over recent years.

I suggest to the House that a decent government which understands it has a role in creating jobs, especially in regional Australia, would, firstly, put more resources into infrastructure development; secondly, provide support for government services to regional Australia so that they were available equally to all Australians; thirdly, support local export driven job initiatives with innovative programs backed by government resources; and, fourthly, provide incentives for migrants to settle in regional Australia rather than metropolitan Australia, especially those migrants who can help kick-start the local economy. I think that view is reinforced by a report in the Age today entitled `It's the city or bust for jobs'.

The suggestions I put forward today are about rebuilding regional Australia. They are about effectively saying that this government has the responsibility to not only ensure additional jobs are created in suburban areas in cities like Melbourne and Sydney but also to ensure support in areas such as Mackay, in Queensland, or Gippsland, in Victoria, aimed at trying to create jobs in regional Australia. That is especially important because, in a lot of those areas, restructuring has wiped out thousands of jobs in industries that were previously exceptionally important to the creation of jobs as well as for the training of our future skills base. They were areas of employment that encouraged apprenticeship training.

I refer, for example, to industries such as electricity generation and steel—industries which the member for Paterson, who is in the House, understands the importance of for the Hunter region—and commercial and government services which are, unfortunately, becoming more and more concentrated in the cities to the detriment of regional Australia. If there are any doubts about that, I will refer to what has occurred in Gippsland in Victoria in recent times. I note from the figures that in Gippsland alone we have seen 18,900 jobs lost since 1995, or 20 per cent of its employment. Other regions of Australia have also suffered huge job losses along the lines of those which occurred in the Gippsland area.

To return to the failure of the government to actually honour its commitment to do something about the issue of manufacturing jobs and its target of 200,000 additional jobs by the year 2000, the minister himself dismissed this with a rather arrogant statement on the Channel 9 Sunday program yesterday. He was asked a fairly relevant question about the need for additional job growth in Australia, especially in industries aimed at maintaining Australia's importance in manufacturing industry. All the minister could say in response was:
Yeah, well, that's not a target we're pursuing in this term.

It seems to me that the new minister for industry—someone who is supposed to be about broadening Australia's manufacturing base, supporting innovation and seeking to attract investment in manufacturing industry in Australia—has merely admitted failure and given up the fight before even trying to do something about manufacturing jobs—especially in regional Australia. I would have thought that a new minister for industry policy would have been about decisive statements that he was going to fight for additional manufacturing jobs in Australia rather than admitting at the outset of his term of office as minister for industry that he is not prepared to stand up for manufacturing industry and that, if anything, he is going to admit failure on the jobs front.

I suppose that represents a continuing trend when it comes to the performance of ministers for industry since the Howard government was elected in March 1996. For example, I refer to the performance of the previous minister for industry, the member for Ryan, Mr Moore. The fall in the figures for manufacturing job growth in the quarter of May, on a seasonally adjusted basis, was 2,300 manufacturing jobs. It worries me even more that in the last year 32,900 manufacturing jobs have been lost, with falls in each of the last three quarters.

If the government actually had a heart and a determination to do something about committing itself to achieving job growth in manufacturing industry, then, after 32 or 33 months in government, we could have expected some job growth in manufacturing industry. If the figures as of June this year were on course, the Prime Minister's government should have created an additional 112,500 new manufacturing jobs by now.

These current figures represent the fact that this government, which has just got back by the skin of its teeth, cannot demonstrate any type of vision for creating jobs for all Australians—especially in manufacturing industry and especially in regional Australia. Instead the key minister, Senator Minchin, who could actually do something about jobs, went on television yesterday and said that they have given up on the promise to create jobs.

All I can say is: what a shameful admission. At a time when it is going to get more competitive and more difficult, the new minister for industry has basically thrown in the towel and said that he is not prepared to commit himself to doing something about this government's promise, prior to the 1996 election, that it was going to achieve 200,000 additional manufacturing jobs by the turn of the century. That is its gift to the nation: yet another failure. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to voice my concerns—and that of many of my constituents—about the domestic violence that takes place in many Aboriginal communities.

speech.para: Like all Australians, I was appalled and horrified by the cases outlined in recent Courier Mail articles by Tony Koch, their chief reporter, and later canvassed by others. It is a very sad fact that these are by no means isolated cases. Women and children in these remote communities face brutality each day of their lives—the kind which no human being should have to endure. That it takes place in this wonderful country, the `lucky country', makes it all the more horrific and intolerable.

There has been much discussion and debate in recent weeks on how this problem should be fixed. I do not pretend to have an easy solution, but two things are very clear. Something must be done to protect these women and children; and just about everyone agrees that alcoholism is the root cause of these violent attacks. One quick and very simple solution that many local residents have raised with me is to remove these women and children from the communities in which they face such danger. As a mother, when I read about these atrocities, that was also one of my immediate reactions. But, of course, to do so would cause an enormous outcry from Aboriginal leaders themselves—with inevitable comparisons to the stolen generation debate.

I do not deny that there are spiritual and cultural issues that need to be considered but, surely, the most important issue is the physical and emotional wellbeing of these women. That is my primary concern. This is not just a matter of lifestyle; it is a matter of life and death. These women and children are being repeatedly beaten and raped. Some are murdered. Police department statistics show that someone living in Doomadgee or Mornington Island is 30 times more likely to be murdered than someone living in any other part of Queensland, and a woman living at Kowanyama is 25 times more likely to be raped. But to take immediate and effective action to prevent this—by removing these people from the dangerous situations—will be seen as an insensitive, thoughtless, `white fella's' solution by those in the Aboriginal industry and the politically correct elites.

In my view, that is a big part of the difficulty we face in trying to improve the situation—any real attempt by the government to improve matters will be described by ATSIC and other privileged Aboriginal leaders as paternalistic—and even racist. Such was the reaction when the Howard government directed ATSIC to spend a greater proportion of their funding on improving health, housing and education, and such was the reaction when we sent in the army to improve housing and sanitary conditions in remote Aboriginal communities. Yet, on the ground, where it really matters, local communities really welcomed these practical measures.

These are some of the basics which commonsense dictates must be priorities. But over the years they have been buried under issues such as political and legal campaigns for land rights and more symbolic issues like reconciliation and formal apologies—and things like the disgraceful issue of Hindmarsh Island where so-called secret women's business was fabricated for cynical political reasons. These political issues must pale in comparison to the personal safety and individual quality of life of innocent children and their mothers.

Part of the problem is that funding for programs to combat family violence is jointly the responsibility of the federal, state and local governments, as well as Aboriginal community groups. For example, in North Queensland, the drafting and enforcement of by-laws to control alcohol consumption are matters for which the Aboriginal communities have responsibility. With alcohol being identified as the root cause of domestic violence problems, it would seem that the ability to improve or at least control the problem in Queensland's remote communities rests with the Aboriginal councils themselves.

That is not to say that the government cannot do more. Since coming to office the Howard government has taken positive steps to get back to the basics and ensure funding is directed where it is needed most—improving health, housing and living standards in Aboriginal communities. No-one wants to see Aboriginal Australians living in Third World conditions. No-one wants to see young Aboriginal children miss out on a decent education. No-one wants to see any Australian suffer disadvantage, which is why so many Australians are still so angry that the previous Labor government wasted billions of dollars without making any real difference to those living in remote Aboriginal communities—because they did not focus on the basics.

There are a number of Howard government programs operating which provide almost $5 million each year just for indigenous family violence programs. Recently, the federal minister also announced that indigenous women would be encouraged to use the resources of the Community Development Employment Project to equip and run women's shelters and run night patrols. The federal Attorney-General's office also run programs to combat violence in indigenous communities as part of their national campaign against violence and crime.

In addition, the Indigenous Family Relationships Support Services will receive $500,000 over the next two years as part of the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence Strategy implemented by the Howard government. This funding will help deliver training on dealing with the victims of domestic violence. Also, under the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, $29 million is provided each year for indigenous clients, with about $18 million of it for family violence situations. These are just a few of the federal programs in place to assist women and children in these remote communities.

Of course, while situations like those outlined in the Courier-Mail persist, it is obvious that we all have to do more, especially the Aboriginal community leaders themselves. I call upon them to make this matter their number one priority. It is a difficult situation. Australians can, however, be assured that the Howard government takes a very different approach from the previous Labor government. We are prepared to do things like send in the Army to provide essential services and assist in improving health conditions in remote communities. We are prepared to challenge ATSIC and make sure that their funding priorities are directed where they are needed most. We have provided increased funding to assist with domestic violence problems. And we do not apologise for this more practical and sensible approach.

But the power to change the situation depends greatly on the will of the Aboriginal leaders who control where the funds are directed. Having visited remote Aboriginal communities in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. I can clearly see that many communities have a distrust of both ATSIC and the white government. The suspicion of government has built up over time, and it limits the ability of the government to offer real solutions—other than the failed way of handing even more money to ATSIC, which was the policy of the previous government and provided no improved outcomes.
Michael Duffy, in an article in the Courier-Mail last month, summed up the approach. He said:

The Hawke and Keating governments tried to solve the political problem by acclaiming small group of pro-ALP, largely male Aboriginal leaders who, in return for money and power, generally approved of the government's actions. These are the leaders who have promoted a form of black pride based on welfare dependency and an overwhelming obsession with land rights, which has helped destroy the self-respect of so many Aboriginal men, leading to alcoholism and brutality . . . the violence to women was largely ignored.
It simply cannot be ignored any longer. The government is taking positive steps, and will continue to do more, but it will take the will of the Aboriginal leaders to really make a difference.

Many of my local constituents have been surprised to learn that we inherited a situation where the minister for Aboriginal affairs does not even have a department; he is advised by ATSIC—which supposedly does the work of a department. But it is, as Michael Duffy described, `committed to the present system and hostile to any criticism or proposals for change', even though Labor's system has clearly created so many problems. And any criticism of ATSIC by the government or individuals is met by calls of racism and the right to self-determination is held aloft as the most important political achievement, not to be questioned or doubted.
In fact, Laurie Kavanaugh, writing in the Courier-Mail, recently made the following point:

The irony is that the community compassion [about this issue] is exactly the same as that which drove past governments to save the lives of mixed-race children, the so-called `stolen generation'. I find that ironic and hope any action taken to stop the bashing of innocent Aboriginal women and children today will be seen by future generations for what it is . . . community action to protect the innocent.

It is a sad fact that, while self-determination might be a personal achievement for those Aboriginal leaders in power, it has done nothing for people like the little three-year-old girl from Kowanyama who has had to wear a colostomy bag for the past two years because she was brutally raped when she was only 17 months old, or for Jacqueline Murray, who has had to endure a lifetime of violent beatings and rapes.

On behalf of the many concerned local residents in Forde, I will continue to work with the Howard government to find ways to protect Aboriginal women and children—in the same way I do for any victim of domestic violence. Most importantly, I call on Aboriginal leaders to make the day-to-day welfare of their people their most pressing concern. All Australians will be more than willing to join them in this endeavour.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Advertising Campaign

talk.start.para: —I want to raise this afternoon the most disgraceful abuse of taxpayers' money for partisan political advantage in the history of our federation. I refer, of course, to the $17 million advertising campaign, paid for with taxpayers' dollars, which promoted the Liberal and National parties' proposal for a goods and services tax. I call this a `disgraceful abuse' for the following reason. The Liberal Party, rather than spend its own money on this promotion, was prepared to put its hand directly into the pockets of taxpayers to fund this massive advertising campaign.

speech.para: I and all other Australians are perfectly well aware that this is not the first time that governments have used taxpayers' dollars in advertising campaigns. But this is both quantitatively and qualitatively quite different from anything we have ever seen from a government before: quantitatively, in that the sheer volume of money spent in a two- to three-week period on an advertising blitz far exceeded any previous examples of taxpayer funded government largesse or indulgence; qualitatively, because the advertising blitz concerned an issue which was not merely political but was the subject of intense partisan dispute. Indeed, it was the main issue on which the federal election in October was fought.

Most government advertising campaigns of the past have been to promote government programs which were not in themselves controversial. The advertising campaign in question might not have enjoyed the opposition's support, but generally the program did. Invariably, in the past the advertising promoted or provided information about a program which was actually being put into effect or about action which the government was in the process of taking. Never before have we seen taxpayers' funds used to promote a matter which was to come before the next parliament after a federal election.

By what moral authority did Prime Minister Howard and Treasurer Costello presume to spend money to promote a tax package which would, had the Liberal Party lost the election, never have seen the light of day? They had no more right to spend that money than did Labor or, for that matter, One Nation or anyone else who felt they might be the next government. They had no right whatsoever to spend taxpayers' dollars on behalf of the next parliament. But was there any attempt at political propriety by allowing Labor or other political parties to also put their case using taxpayer funds? No. This was the exclusive preserve of the Liberal and National parties.

Even though Prime Minister Howard effectively turned the last election into a referendum on the government's tax package—both by calling an election immediately the taxpayer funded blitz was over and by telling the electorate that, if they did not like the GST, they should vote against the government—there was no attempt whatsoever to have a publicly funded no case against the tax package. Instead, $17 million of our money was spent promoting the yes case, trying to tell us that the GST was good for us. It is worth remembering that, despite this, Labor polled better than 51.5 per cent two-party preferred; that is to say, if the election had been a referendum on the GST, the Liberal and National parties would have lost it.

The second matter is how this advertising campaign was used to mislead Australians and, in particular, pensioners and self-funded retirees. I have with me a booklet which rejoices in the name: Tax reform—not a new tax a new tax system. Many Australians will have seen it. I understand that it was distributed to every Australian household, at their expense, by the government.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is true—not through Australia Post. On pages 11 and 12 are examples of how the GST was to impact on age pensioners, part-pensioners and self-funded retirees. On page 11 we have a picture of a smiling Marge and Dave, senior Australians who will, according to this, be $23 a week better off after GST. On the next page we have Doug and Betty, also smiling self-funded retirees, who will, according to the booklet, be $18 a week better off after GST.

speech.para: Obviously, during the campaign people did not have the opportunity to go through and find out—certainly ordinary Australians did not have the opportunity to find out—on what assumptions these rosy outcomes were based. But, having had the opportunity to do that and, in particular, having had my attention drawn to some of the assumptions in the calculations by the ARPA Over Fifties Association Ltd—and, in particular, by Mr Bill Dow, who has done quite a lot of work going through these assumptions—I was able to draw the attention of the parliament and the Australian people to a number of things that you did not read about if you made your way conscientiously through this booklet.

Firstly, there was no allowance made for the abolition of the savings rebate. The savings rebate was a measure which the Howard government promoted after it abandoned—in my view, wrongly—Labor's proposal for government co-contributions to superannuation. The savings rebate was no small matter, indeed, it was of the order of a $2 billion cost in the year 2000-01: $2 billion to be spent on the savings rebate—a rebate of up to $450 for people who were entitled to it. But the fact that the government was proposing to abolish the savings rebate and that therefore people would be worse off under the tax package than they would be without it, was not included in the tables which we see on page 11 and page 12. Perhaps Marge and Dave and Doug and Betty would not be smiling if they were aware of the fact that abolition of the savings rebate is not included in there and that they therefore would not have the sums that they thought they might get.

Secondly, there is no reference in these tables to the possible implications of the assets test. It is very interesting to look at what they are proposing for age pensioner couples. They talk about an increase in social security payments of the order of $50 a week, $60 a week or $70 a week as against $25,000, $30,000 or $35,000 in private income. You do not need to be Einstein to realise that, if you are generating $25,000, $30,000 or $35,000 in private income, there is a fair chance that there is a significant asset backing behind that and a significant risk that you will be caught through the assets test and therefore will not be eligible for the age pension and will not get the benefits that you are told here you will get. Nevertheless, the government chose to make no allowance in its calculations—not in the larger tax package and certainly not in the shorter form which was provided to all Australian households—for the fact that the assets test was not included in these calculations.

Thirdly, they included in their calculations the aged persons savings bonus of up to $1,000 for pensioners and up to $3,000 for self-funded retirees, a one-off bonus. Yet on this basis they are prepared to say that Marge and Dave will be $23 a week better off after paying the GST. The fact is: after year one Marge and Dave will not have access to that bonus and their circumstances will change substantially. If we were able to redo these calculations—I believe the government owes it to the electorate to redo them—taking into account the impact of the abolition of the savings rebate, the impact of assets testing and the fact that the aged persons savings bonus is a one-off, I believe we would find a very different picture indeed concerning the impact of the GST on over two million retired Australians, both pensioners and self-funded retirees. It is quite disgraceful that the government saw fit to spend so much taxpayers' money to provide such a misleading picture as to how the GST would impact upon retired Australians. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —With Christmas almost upon us, I thought I would take the opportunity today in the grievance debate to acknowledge the work done by charities towards Christmas for people who are in need and are not as fortunate as we are in this place. I had an interesting time following through this line of thought today as I rang the charities. I really wanted to acknowledge the work they were doing and to speak to them about that work. I found a common thread in what they were saying; that is, that demand for their services has gone up. The Glenelg Uniting Church community aid program in my electorate of Hindmarsh said demand was up 30 per cent—that was the only centre which actually gave a figure. The other charitable organisation said that they had noticed a similar increase.

speech.para: I asked what was the cause of this. There were various suggestions, none of which really held up. Perhaps I could look at one because it shows how easy it is to pick on one problem or on what one hears and assume it is the answer.

The Adelaide Day Care Centre suggested that there is an increased number of people whose phones were being disconnected, whose electricity was being cut off and who could no longer meet their electricity payments. I thought, if this is indeed happening, it is a serious problem which we would have to address. So I contacted the utilities in South Australia and found that, according to the statistics, things are not getting worse. For instance, the figure for non-payment of electricity bills in 1995-96 was 9,800. In 1997-98, that had decreased to 7,785. Similarly, extensions of payments were down this year compared with last year, although not hugely—in 1996-97, it was 266,000 persons and, in 1997-98, 263,000 persons.

Telstra told me a similar story. As far as they could work out, without pulling out actual figures, there had been no increase in defaults. Similarly, the gas company which was named by the charities, in 1995, had had 11,675 disconnections. In 1997, disconnections had dropped to 11,394. Although it seemed to be a general theme that part of the problem had been an increase in utilities bills—I know these organisations meet and discuss these issues—when you look at disconnections and extended payments, this does not seem to be the problem. I do not question that, for all these organisations, demand on their time and money is going up.

I was interested to talk to another organisation in my electorate, the Church of Christ community care at Torrensville. I spoke there to Lynda Baird who had worked in Ireland. She had a somewhat different idea of what might be happening. In this sense, she brought my speech in the grievance debate round full circle because I had intended to acknowledge those who are isolated in the community, who do not have the ability to share Christmas with family and do not have money to expend on Christmas the way advertising exhorts us to. Talking to Lynda, we came full circle because she put isolation as one of the root causes for the financial problems that people are experiencing. This drew together a whole lot of suggestions from other charities.

They had mentioned alcohol, cigarettes, gambling, poor budgeting, drugs and use of the 0055 and the 1900 telephone numbers. Lynda acknowledged all these as problems but took them all back to the problem of isolation. She said there are a lot more people in the community now who, through divorce, family breakdown and retrenchment, are living alone or are living in fairly isolated circumstances of just one or two—a husband and a wife, a mother and child, a father and a child. She pointed out that in these circumstances there is a greater tendency to turn for relief to alcohol or to cigarettes. When I was smoking many years ago, in tense situations you were very much aware that, if you had no friends in the world, at least there was a cigarette in your hand to hold on to. I am sure that still applies.

Gambling, for people who live alone, who go into the hotels in an atmosphere where there are people around them, to sit there and have something to do, relieves that sense of isolation. Drugs are also an escape from bad situations and from situations where people feel isolated. I was told stories of young girls and young men who, faced with isolation, took to drugs and found that that was not an answer to their problem. Unfortunately, some of them ended up committing suicide, just from the sheer isolation of living alone, from the sense of being alone.

Another issue, which I had not thought of, was bad budgeting or inappropriate purchases. It was drawn to my attention that a man had come to the church looking for help with monetary and other problems, but outside he had a flashy car. The woman I was talking about earlier had asked the chap where he had got his car. He said, `I just bought it.' She looked at that car and realised how much it meant to him but realised that he would own it for a month, if he was lucky. He did not have the income to buy that car. His purchase of the car was, again, an offset for his own misery; it was something to do. For some small amount of joy to come into his life, he bought the car on hire purchase because it would give him immediate pleasure. But, of course, the money was never going to be there to pay for it, and it was inevitable that the hire purchase company would reclaim that car within the month.

This extends to other purchases, for instance, brand new colour television sets or cable television from Foxtel—anything that will make the isolated life seem just that little bit better and give the feeling that some of that loneliness will abate if there is an opportunity to watch a whole range of different programs; and that is not the situation.

I am reminded of some words of Melina Mercouri, the Greek actress who became a great Greek stateswoman. When asked why in Greece they had no psychiatrists, she said, `In Greece we do not need psychiatrists, we have friends.' I think that probably provides some comment on the degree of dysfunction you see in some of these people who have been isolated and for whom the community is not giving anything back.

I also have some comments on the reaction of people in Australia to requests from charities for both physical assistance—as in volun teers—and donations. It was observed that the people who donate tend to be the older people who have less to donate. The experience of many of the collectors is that, when they go to homes where two people work, such as the husband and the wife, those people are less likely to give than the one-person household, and certainly less likely to give than the one-person household where the person is older. I have had a similar experience when I have collected for charities: the absolute frustration you feel when you are turned back by somebody with a Jaguar parked in the driveway while somebody in a small house goes through her purse to try and find $1, when she is having trouble meeting her rent payments.

Finally, let me note that in Australia we give $38 a head to charity every year. That compares with $642 per head in Canada and a massive $2,455 per person in the US. At this stage, there is only time to wonder if that is because our very wealthy people and our wealthy corporations do not match those in other countries with their giving. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I raise again the issue of disruption to people's lives caused by the often insensitive way the child support system works. Over the last few months a number of media articles have been very critical of non-custodial parents and their claim for a fairer deal in regard to child support. Because I have received many representations on this matter—as, no doubt, all of my colleagues have—I encouraged the establishment of a fairness in child support group in the Illawarra. Despite what some critics in the Illawarra say, this group is not a `men only' group. Both men and women established this group following a public meeting that I convened.

speech.para: People involved in FICS are making a few reasonable demands of the child support system. One of the most important is the way child support contributions are assessed. Contributions should be assessed on a parent's net yearly wage or salary, not on their gross earnings. Many argue that there must be greater accountability for the money. Many people have to work overtime to make their commitments—that is, when overtime is available—to make up for the shortfall in their pay at the end of each fortnight, but this increases their assessable income. For many people it is a catch-22 situation: what is the point of working overtime when your payments will go up? People come and say to me all the time, `I would be better off going away somewhere on the dole.' This is happening time and time again.

It is true that few people I see in my office are satisfied with the current child support legislation. The child support issue is the final straw for many people following a difficult relationship breakdown, property settlement and access battle. The people who come to see me—and I am sure my colleagues will agree—are angry, frustrated and bitter.

What concerns me is that bureaucracy causes the bitterness generated by so many cases. I have great sympathy for the workers in the Child Support Agency. Managing the system is not an easy position to be in. They are also the focal point for much anger and bitterness. People feel as if they are constantly bashing their heads against a brick wall, that nobody listens and no-one understands their problems. It is very rare for me to hear from any parent who does not want to contribute to the upbringing of his or her child or children, but contributions must be assessed in a fair and reasonable way.

The other issue is that, in many cases, children are being used to hurt former partners in a relationship. Crudely put, children are being used as pawns. In no way do I want to see a return to the days when women were abandoned by male partners, leaving them with no financial support to raise the children. This was the reason why the child support legislation was originally introduced.

I never want to see a return to the days when the custodial parent was left in the financial lurch. But we must come up with a better, fairer and reasonable way to assess contributions. The bitterness and anger that stains the child support debate will be removed by just resolving this issue.

Many of the people who see me are men, and their second partner usually accompanies them. Too many non-custodial parents are unable to establish new relationships because they feel they are unable to offer their new partner security. Non-custodial parents, after paying their taxes and child support contributions, are left with very little to live on. Many cannot afford rent and return to live with their parents. Many times I have seen people who have had their own homes having to return to live with their parents after their relationships have gone wrong.

I believe the legislation as it stands today discriminates against the non-custodial parent. This covers both men and women, but it is a fact that the majority of non-custodial parents are men. Non-custodial parents from broken relationships are finding it too difficult to move on with their lives. They find it difficult to establish a second relationship. In many cases, when they succeed in establishing a second relationship, the children from this relationship are disadvantaged compared with the children of the first relationship.

I am aware of cases where the second wife or partner has had to find employment to assist her partner in meeting child support liabilities from the first relationship. Surely, this is not what the current child support legislation intended when it was introduced. In another recent case, a woman contacted me because her former husband was not paying child support at all. He happens to be a successful businessman in the Illawarra—he has four businesses in different suburbs of Wollongong. The children receive Austudy payments because of his low income but his former wife's pension entitlement has been reduced because her pension is less the income that he receives from the four businesses. It is usually men who have such relationships and often they can so arrange their financial dealings that they do not have to meet their rightful requirements.

I was surprised to read an article in the Sun-Herald of 27 September 1998 entitled `Suffer the Little Children: Tug of Love'. The article claims that non-custodial parents tend to spoil their children while on contact visits, causing problems for the child and the custodial parent. The article quotes an example:

When they're together, it's junk food and late nights and it takes days to calm Jessica down when she comes home . . . He's always buying her expensive gifts, things I just can't afford. He looks like the fun parent and I look miserable and mean.
From my experience, by the time the non-custodial parent pays out child support, there is very little left over for the parent to be able to buy expensive gifts for their child.
